trans-unit.source: Deploy an existing application in Azure Service Fabric
trans-unit.target: Deploy an existing application in Azure Service Fabric

trans-unit.source: Walkthrough on how to package an existing application so it can be deployed on an Azure Service Fabric cluster
trans-unit.target: Walkthrough on how to package an existing application so it can be deployed on an Azure Service Fabric cluster

trans-unit.source: Deploy an existing application in Azure Service Fabric
trans-unit.target: Deploy an existing application in Azure Service Fabric

trans-unit.source: Azure Service Fabric can be used to deploy existing applications.
trans-unit.target: Azure Service Fabric can be used to deploy existing applications.

trans-unit.source: Applications that currently runs on, for instance, an Azure Web or Worker role, can be 'packaged' so that they can be deployed on an Service Fabric cluster.
trans-unit.target: Applications that currently runs on, for instance, an Azure Web or Worker role, can be 'packaged' so that they can be deployed on an Service Fabric cluster.

trans-unit.source: Existing applications running on a Service Fabric cluster can benefit from features such as health monitoring and ALM (Application Lifecycle Management) so it is an important scenario that is fully supported.
trans-unit.target: Existing applications running on a Service Fabric cluster can benefit from features such as health monitoring and ALM (Application Lifecycle Management) so it is an important scenario that is fully supported.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial explains the process and basic concepts that are involved with taking an existing application and package it.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial explains the process and basic concepts that are involved with taking an existing application and package it.

trans-unit.source: This article that is an overview of the process, we will follow up with specific examples on how to take an existing applications (for instance a node.js or Java) app and package it so it can be hosted on a Service Fabric cluster.
trans-unit.target: This article that is an overview of the process, we will follow up with specific examples on how to take an existing applications (for instance a node.js or Java) app and package it so it can be hosted on a Service Fabric cluster.

trans-unit.source: Quick overview of Application and Service manifest files
trans-unit.target: Quick overview of Application and Service manifest files

trans-unit.source: Before we can start and learn how to package an existing application, we need to go through an brief introduction of the Service Fabric's deployment model.
trans-unit.target: Before we can start and learn how to package an existing application, we need to go through an brief introduction of the Service Fabric's deployment model.

trans-unit.source: Service Fabric deployment model relies mainly on two files:
trans-unit.target: Service Fabric deployment model relies mainly on two files:

trans-unit.source: Application Manifest.
trans-unit.target: Application Manifest.

trans-unit.source: The application manifest is used to describe the application and lists the services that compose it plus other parameters, such as the number of instances, that are used to define how the service(s) should be deployed.In the Service Fabric world, an application is the 'upgradable unit'.
trans-unit.target: The application manifest is used to describe the application and lists the services that compose it plus other parameters, such as the number of instances, that are used to define how the service(s) should be deployed.In the Service Fabric world, an application is the 'upgradable unit'.

trans-unit.source: An application can be upgraded as a single unit where potential failures (and potential rollbacks) are managed by the platform to guarantee that the upgrade process either completely success or, if it fails, it does not leave the application is an unknown/unstable state.
trans-unit.target: An application can be upgraded as a single unit where potential failures (and potential rollbacks) are managed by the platform to guarantee that the upgrade process either completely success or, if it fails, it does not leave the application is an unknown/unstable state.

trans-unit.source: This is an example of an application manifest:
trans-unit.target: This is an example of an application manifest:

trans-unit.source: Service Manifest.
trans-unit.target: Service Manifest.

trans-unit.source: Service Manifest describes the components of a service.
trans-unit.target: Service Manifest describes the components of a service.

trans-unit.source: It includes data such as name and type of the service (information that Service Fabric uses to manage the service), its code, configuration and data components plus some additional parameters that can be used to configure the service once it is deployed.
trans-unit.target: It includes data such as name and type of the service (information that Service Fabric uses to manage the service), its code, configuration and data components plus some additional parameters that can be used to configure the service once it is deployed.

trans-unit.source: We are not going into the details of all the different parameters available in the service manifest, we will go through the subset that is required to make an existing application to run on Service Fabric
trans-unit.target: We are not going into the details of all the different parameters available in the service manifest, we will go through the subset that is required to make an existing application to run on Service Fabric

trans-unit.source: This is an example of a service manifest
trans-unit.target: This is an example of a service manifest

trans-unit.source: Application Package file structure
trans-unit.target: Application Package file structure

trans-unit.source: In order to deploy an application using, for instance, the powershell cmdlets, the application needs to follow a predefined directory structure.
trans-unit.target: In order to deploy an application using, for instance, the powershell cmdlets, the application needs to follow a predefined directory structure.

trans-unit.source: \applicationmanifest.xml
trans-unit.target: \applicationmanifest.xml

trans-unit.source: \MyServicePkg
trans-unit.target: \MyServicePkg

trans-unit.source: \servicemanifest.xml
trans-unit.target: \servicemanifest.xml

trans-unit.source: \code
trans-unit.target: \code

trans-unit.source: \config
trans-unit.target: \config

trans-unit.source: \data
trans-unit.target: \data

trans-unit.source: The root contains the applicationmanifest.xml file that defines the application.
trans-unit.target: The root contains the applicationmanifest.xml file that defines the application.

trans-unit.source: A subdirectory for each service included in the application is used to contain all the artifacts that the service requires: The servicemanifest.xml and, typically 3 directories:
trans-unit.target: A subdirectory for each service included in the application is used to contain all the artifacts that the service requires: The servicemanifest.xml and, typically 3 directories:

trans-unit.source: code: contains the service code
trans-unit.target: code: contains the service code

trans-unit.source: config: contains a settings.xml file (and other files if necessary) that the service can access at runtime to retrieve specific configuration settings.
trans-unit.target: config: contains a settings.xml file (and other files if necessary) that the service can access at runtime to retrieve specific configuration settings.

trans-unit.source: Data: an additional directory to store additional local data that service may need.
trans-unit.target: Data: an additional directory to store additional local data that service may need.

trans-unit.source: Note: Data should be used to store only ephymeral data, Service Fabric does not copy/replicate changes to the data directory if the service needs to be relocated, for instance, during failover.
trans-unit.target: Note: Data should be used to store only ephymeral data, Service Fabric does not copy/replicate changes to the data directory if the service needs to be relocated, for instance, during failover.

trans-unit.source: Note: You can use any arbitrary directory name for Code, Config and Data.
trans-unit.target: Note: You can use any arbitrary directory name for Code, Config and Data.

trans-unit.source: You should need to make sure to use the same value in the ApplicationManifest file.
trans-unit.target: You should need to make sure to use the same value in the ApplicationManifest file.

trans-unit.source: the process of packaging an existing app
trans-unit.target: the process of packaging an existing app

trans-unit.source: The process of packaging an existing application is based on the following steps:
trans-unit.target: The process of packaging an existing application is based on the following steps:

trans-unit.source: Create the package directory structure
trans-unit.target: Create the package directory structure

trans-unit.source: Add application's code and configuration files
trans-unit.target: Add application's code and configuration files

trans-unit.source: update the service manifest file
trans-unit.target: update the service manifest file

trans-unit.source: update the application manifest
trans-unit.target: update the application manifest

trans-unit.source: Create the package directory structure
trans-unit.target: Create the package directory structure

trans-unit.source: You can start by creating the directory structure as described above.
trans-unit.target: You can start by creating the directory structure as described above.

trans-unit.source: I created a directory and copied the application and service manifest from an existing project that I previously had created in Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: I created a directory and copied the application and service manifest from an existing project that I previously had created in Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: Add the application's code and configuration files
trans-unit.target: Add the application's code and configuration files

trans-unit.source: After you have created the directory structure, you can add the application's code and configuration files under the Code and Config directory.
trans-unit.target: After you have created the directory structure, you can add the application's code and configuration files under the Code and Config directory.

trans-unit.source: You can also create additional directories or sub directories under the Code or Config directories.
trans-unit.target: You can also create additional directories or sub directories under the Code or Config directories.

trans-unit.source: Service Fabric does an xcopy of the content of the application root directory so there is no predefined structure to use other than creating two top directories Code and Settings (but you can pick different names if you want, more details in the next section).
trans-unit.target: Service Fabric does an xcopy of the content of the application root directory so there is no predefined structure to use other than creating two top directories Code and Settings (but you can pick different names if you want, more details in the next section).

trans-unit.source: !Azure Note: Make sure that you include all the files/dependencies that the application needs.
trans-unit.target: !Azure Note: Make sure that you include all the files/dependencies that the application needs.

trans-unit.source: Service Fabric will copy the content of the application package on all nodes in the cluster where the application's services are going to be deployed.
trans-unit.target: Service Fabric will copy the content of the application package on all nodes in the cluster where the application's services are going to be deployed.

trans-unit.source: The package should contain all the code that the application needs in order to run.
trans-unit.target: The package should contain all the code that the application needs in order to run.

trans-unit.source: It is not recommended to assume that the dependencies are already installed.
trans-unit.target: It is not recommended to assume that the dependencies are already installed.

trans-unit.source: Edit the Service Manifest file
trans-unit.target: Edit the Service Manifest file

trans-unit.source: The next step is to edit the Service Manifest file to include the following information:
trans-unit.target: The next step is to edit the Service Manifest file to include the following information:

trans-unit.source: The name of the service type.
trans-unit.target: The name of the service type.

trans-unit.source: This is an 'Id' that Service Fabric uses in order to identify a service
trans-unit.target: This is an 'Id' that Service Fabric uses in order to identify a service

trans-unit.source: The command to use to launch the application (ExeHost)
trans-unit.target: The command to use to launch the application (ExeHost)

trans-unit.source: Any script that needs to be run in order to setup/configure the application (SetupEntrypoint
trans-unit.target: Any script that needs to be run in order to setup/configure the application (SetupEntrypoint

trans-unit.source: This is an example of a servicemanifest.xnml file that 'packages' a node.js application:
trans-unit.target: This is an example of a servicemanifest.xnml file that 'packages' a node.js application:

trans-unit.source: Let's go over the different part of the file that you need to update:
trans-unit.target: Let's go over the different part of the file that you need to update:

trans-unit.source: ServiceTypes:
trans-unit.target: ServiceTypes:

trans-unit.source: You can pick any name that you want for ServiceTypeName, the value is used in the applicationmanifest.xml to identify the service.
trans-unit.target: You can pick any name that you want for ServiceTypeName, the value is used in the applicationmanifest.xml to identify the service.

trans-unit.source: You need to specify UserImplicitHost = "true".
trans-unit.target: You need to specify UserImplicitHost = "true".

trans-unit.source: This attribute tells Service Fabric that the service is based on a self-contained app so that it needs to do is just to launch it as a process and monitor its health.
trans-unit.target: This attribute tells Service Fabric that the service is based on a self-contained app so that it needs to do is just to launch it as a process and monitor its health.

trans-unit.source: CodePackage
trans-unit.target: CodePackage

trans-unit.source: The CodePackage specifies the location (and version) of the service's code.
trans-unit.target: The CodePackage specifies the location (and version) of the service's code.

trans-unit.source: The Name element is used to specify the name of the directory in the Application Package that contains the service's code.
trans-unit.target: The Name element is used to specify the name of the directory in the Application Package that contains the service's code.

trans-unit.source: CodePackage also has the version attribute that can be used to specify the version of the code and, potentially, be used to upgrade the service's code by leveraging Service Fabric's Application LifeCycle Management infrastructure.
trans-unit.target: CodePackage also has the version attribute that can be used to specify the version of the code and, potentially, be used to upgrade the service's code by leveraging Service Fabric's Application LifeCycle Management infrastructure.

trans-unit.source: Entrypoint
trans-unit.target: Entrypoint

trans-unit.source: The Entrypoint element in the service manifest file is used to specify how to launch the service.
trans-unit.target: The Entrypoint element in the service manifest file is used to specify how to launch the service.

trans-unit.source: The ExeHost element specifies the executable (and arguments) that should be used to launch the service.
trans-unit.target: The ExeHost element specifies the executable (and arguments) that should be used to launch the service.

trans-unit.source: Program:specifies the name of the executable that should be executed in order to start the service.
trans-unit.target: Program:specifies the name of the executable that should be executed in order to start the service.

trans-unit.source: Arguments: it specifies the arguments that should be passed to the executable.
trans-unit.target: Arguments: it specifies the arguments that should be passed to the executable.

trans-unit.source: it can be a list of parameters with arguments.
trans-unit.target: it can be a list of parameters with arguments.

trans-unit.source: WorkingFolder: it specifies the working directory for the process that is going to be started.
trans-unit.target: WorkingFolder: it specifies the working directory for the process that is going to be started.

trans-unit.source: You can specify two values:
trans-unit.target: You can specify two values:

trans-unit.source: CodeBase: the working directory is going to be set to the Code directory in the application package (Code directory in the structure shown below)
trans-unit.target: CodeBase: the working directory is going to be set to the Code directory in the application package (Code directory in the structure shown below)

trans-unit.source: CodePackage: the working directory will be set to the root of the application package (MyServicePkg)
trans-unit.target: CodePackage: the working directory will be set to the root of the application package (MyServicePkg)

trans-unit.source: WorkingDirectory element is useful to set the correct working directory so relative paths can be used by either the application or initialization scripts.
trans-unit.target: WorkingDirectory element is useful to set the correct working directory so relative paths can be used by either the application or initialization scripts.

trans-unit.source: There is also another value that you can specify for the WorkingFolder element (Work) but it is not very useful for the scenario of bringing an existing application.
trans-unit.target: There is also another value that you can specify for the WorkingFolder element (Work) but it is not very useful for the scenario of bringing an existing application.

trans-unit.source: The setup entry point
trans-unit.target: The setup entry point

trans-unit.source: The SetupEntrypoint is used to specify any executable or batch file that should be executed before the service's code is launched.
trans-unit.target: The SetupEntrypoint is used to specify any executable or batch file that should be executed before the service's code is launched.

trans-unit.source: It is an optional element so it does not need to be included if there is no intialization/setup that is required.
trans-unit.target: It is an optional element so it does not need to be included if there is no intialization/setup that is required.

trans-unit.source: The Entrypoint is executed every time the service is restarted.
trans-unit.target: The Entrypoint is executed every time the service is restarted.

trans-unit.source: There is only one SetupEntrypoint so setup/config scripts needs to be boundled on a single batch file if the application's setup/config requires multiple scripts.
trans-unit.target: There is only one SetupEntrypoint so setup/config scripts needs to be boundled on a single batch file if the application's setup/config requires multiple scripts.

trans-unit.source: Like the Entrypoint element, SetupEntrypoint can execute any type of file: executable, batch fiules, powershell cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: Like the Entrypoint element, SetupEntrypoint can execute any type of file: executable, batch fiules, powershell cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: In the example above, the SetupEntrypoint is based on a batch file myAppsetup.cmd that is located in the scripts subdirectory of the Code directory (assuming the WorkingDirectory element is set to Code).
trans-unit.target: In the example above, the SetupEntrypoint is based on a batch file myAppsetup.cmd that is located in the scripts subdirectory of the Code directory (assuming the WorkingDirectory element is set to Code).

trans-unit.source: Application Manifest file
trans-unit.target: Application Manifest file

trans-unit.source: Once you have configured the servicemanifest.xml file you need to make some changes to the applicationmanifest.xml file to ensure the correct Service type and name are used.
trans-unit.target: Once you have configured the servicemanifest.xml file you need to make some changes to the applicationmanifest.xml file to ensure the correct Service type and name are used.

trans-unit.source: ServiceManifestImport
trans-unit.target: ServiceManifestImport

trans-unit.source: In the ServiceManifestImport you can specify one or more services that you want to include in the app.
trans-unit.target: In the ServiceManifestImport you can specify one or more services that you want to include in the app.

trans-unit.source: Services are referenced with ServiceManifestName that specifies the name of the directory where the servicemanifest.xml file is located.
trans-unit.target: Services are referenced with ServiceManifestName that specifies the name of the directory where the servicemanifest.xml file is located.

trans-unit.source: DefaultServices
trans-unit.target: DefaultServices

trans-unit.source: The DefaultServices element in the application manifest file is used to define some service properties.
trans-unit.target: The DefaultServices element in the application manifest file is used to define some service properties.

trans-unit.source: ServiceTypeName is used as an 'Id' for the service.
trans-unit.target: ServiceTypeName is used as an 'Id' for the service.

trans-unit.source: in the context of porting an existing application, ServiceTypeName just need to be a unique identifies for your service.
trans-unit.target: in the context of porting an existing application, ServiceTypeName just need to be a unique identifies for your service.

trans-unit.source: StatelessService: Service Fabric supports two types of services: Stateless and Stateful.
trans-unit.target: StatelessService: Service Fabric supports two types of services: Stateless and Stateful.

trans-unit.source: In the case of porting an existing application the service is a stateless service so StatelessService should always be used.
trans-unit.target: In the case of porting an existing application the service is a stateless service so StatelessService should always be used.

trans-unit.source: A Service Fabric service can be deployed in various 'configurations', for instance it can be deployed as a single or multiple instances or it can be deployed in such a way that there is one instance of the service on each node of the Service Fabric cluster.
trans-unit.target: A Service Fabric service can be deployed in various 'configurations', for instance it can be deployed as a single or multiple instances or it can be deployed in such a way that there is one instance of the service on each node of the Service Fabric cluster.

trans-unit.source: In the applicationmanifest.xml file you can specify how you want the application to be deployed
trans-unit.target: In the applicationmanifest.xml file you can specify how you want the application to be deployed

trans-unit.source: InstanceCount: is used to specify how many instances of the service should be launched in the Service Fabric cluster.
trans-unit.target: InstanceCount: is used to specify how many instances of the service should be launched in the Service Fabric cluster.

trans-unit.source: You can set the InstanceCount value depending on the type of application that you are deploying.
trans-unit.target: You can set the InstanceCount value depending on the type of application that you are deploying.

trans-unit.source: The two most common scenarios are:
trans-unit.target: The two most common scenarios are:

trans-unit.source: InstanCount = "1": in this case only one instance of the service will be deployed on the cluster.
trans-unit.target: InstanCount = "1": in this case only one instance of the service will be deployed on the cluster.

trans-unit.source: Service Fabric's scheduler determines on which node the service is going to be deployed.
trans-unit.target: Service Fabric's scheduler determines on which node the service is going to be deployed.

trans-unit.source: A single instance count also makes sense for applications that require a different configuration if they run on multiple instances.
trans-unit.target: A single instance count also makes sense for applications that require a different configuration if they run on multiple instances.

trans-unit.source: In that case it is easier to define multiple services in the same application manifest file and use InstanceCount = "1".
trans-unit.target: In that case it is easier to define multiple services in the same application manifest file and use InstanceCount = "1".

trans-unit.source: So the end result will be to have multiple instances of the same service but each with a specific configuration.
trans-unit.target: So the end result will be to have multiple instances of the same service but each with a specific configuration.

trans-unit.source: A value of InstanceCount greater than one makes sense only if the goal is to have multiple instance of the exact same configuration.
trans-unit.target: A value of InstanceCount greater than one makes sense only if the goal is to have multiple instance of the exact same configuration.

trans-unit.source: InstanceCount ="-1": in this case one instance of the service will be deployed on every node in the Service Fabric cluster.
trans-unit.target: InstanceCount ="-1": in this case one instance of the service will be deployed on every node in the Service Fabric cluster.

trans-unit.source: The end result will be having one (and only one) instance of the service for each node in the cluster.
trans-unit.target: The end result will be having one (and only one) instance of the service for each node in the cluster.

trans-unit.source: This is a useful configuration for front-end applications (ex.
trans-unit.target: This is a useful configuration for front-end applications (ex.

trans-unit.source: a REST endpoint) because client applications just need to 'connect' to any of the node in the cluster in order to use the endpoint.
trans-unit.target: a REST endpoint) because client applications just need to 'connect' to any of the node in the cluster in order to use the endpoint.

trans-unit.source: This configuration can also be used when, for instance, all nodes of the Service Fabric cluster are connected to a load balancer so client traffic can be distributed across the service running on all nodes in the cluster.
trans-unit.target: This configuration can also be used when, for instance, all nodes of the Service Fabric cluster are connected to a load balancer so client traffic can be distributed across the service running on all nodes in the cluster.

trans-unit.source: Testing
trans-unit.target: Testing

trans-unit.source: For existing application is very useful to be able to see console logs to find out if the application and configuration scripts don't show any error.
trans-unit.target: For existing application is very useful to be able to see console logs to find out if the application and configuration scripts don't show any error.

trans-unit.source: Console redirection can be configured in the servicemanifest.xml file using the ConsoleRedirection element
trans-unit.target: Console redirection can be configured in the servicemanifest.xml file using the ConsoleRedirection element

trans-unit.source: ConsoleRedirection can be used to redirect console output (both stdout and stderr) to a working directory so they can be used to verify that there are no errors during the setup or execution of the application in the Service Fabric cluster.
trans-unit.target: ConsoleRedirection can be used to redirect console output (both stdout and stderr) to a working directory so they can be used to verify that there are no errors during the setup or execution of the application in the Service Fabric cluster.

trans-unit.source: FileRetentionCount determines how many files are saved in the working directory.
trans-unit.target: FileRetentionCount determines how many files are saved in the working directory.

trans-unit.source: A value of, for instance, 5 means that the log files for the previous 5 executions are stored in the working directory.
trans-unit.target: A value of, for instance, 5 means that the log files for the previous 5 executions are stored in the working directory.

trans-unit.source: FileMaxSizeInKb specifies the max size of the log files.
trans-unit.target: FileMaxSizeInKb specifies the max size of the log files.

trans-unit.source: Log files are saved on one of the service's working directories, in order to determine where the files are located, you need to use the Service Fabric Explorer to determine in which node the service is running and which is the working directory that is currently used.
trans-unit.target: Log files are saved on one of the service's working directories, in order to determine where the files are located, you need to use the Service Fabric Explorer to determine in which node the service is running and which is the working directory that is currently used.

trans-unit.source: In the Service Fabric explorer, identify the node where the service is running
trans-unit.target: In the Service Fabric explorer, identify the node where the service is running

trans-unit.source: After you know the node where the service is currently running, you can find out which is the working directory used
trans-unit.target: After you know the node where the service is currently running, you can find out which is the working directory used

trans-unit.source: When you select the name of the service, on the right panel you can see there the service code and settings are stored
trans-unit.target: When you select the name of the service, on the right panel you can see there the service code and settings are stored

trans-unit.source: If you click on the link in the 'Disk Location' field you can access the directory where the services is running on.
trans-unit.target: If you click on the link in the 'Disk Location' field you can access the directory where the services is running on.

trans-unit.source: The log directory contains all log files.
trans-unit.target: The log directory contains all log files.

trans-unit.source: Note: This example shows the case of a single instance of the service running in the cluster.
trans-unit.target: Note: This example shows the case of a single instance of the service running in the cluster.

trans-unit.source: If there are multiple instances you may need to check the log file on all the nodes where the service is running.
trans-unit.target: If there are multiple instances you may need to check the log file on all the nodes where the service is running.

trans-unit.source: What's next
trans-unit.target: What's next

trans-unit.source: We are working on a tools that can be used to package an existing application simply by pointing it at the root of the directory structure of the app.
trans-unit.target: We are working on a tools that can be used to package an existing application simply by pointing it at the root of the directory structure of the app.

trans-unit.source: The tool takes care of generate the manifest files and configure the basic settings that are required to 'transform' the application in a Service Fabric service.
trans-unit.target: The tool takes care of generate the manifest files and configure the basic settings that are required to 'transform' the application in a Service Fabric service.
